FuncDef:
The ppp mru-negotiate command enables maximum receive unit (MRU) negotiation at the PPP link control layer.
The undo ppp mru-negotiate command restores the default negotiation mode.
By default, the PPP link control layer performs the IPv4 MRU negotiation.

ParaDef.Info:
Enables the IPv6 MRU negotiation at the PPP link control layer.
-

Enables the IPv4 MRU negotiation at the PPP link control layer.
-

ExtraInfo:
Usage Scenario
The MRU indicates the capability of an interface on receiving packets. By default, the IPv4 MRU negotiation is performed at the link control layer. If an interface is configured with the IPv6 MTU, the IPv6 MRU negotiation can be performed at the link control layer only after the interface is enabled with PPP IPv6 MRU negotiation. When the negotiation ends, the MTU of the link adopts the smaller one of the MTUs (the negotiated MRUs) of the two interfaces, and the MRUs of the two interfaces do not change. Therefore, the MTU of an interface cannot be greater than the MRU of the interface, which ensures that both ends are capable of receiving packets from each other.
After a PPP link is set up, it performs LCP negotiation. If MRU negotiation is enabled, the MRU of the PPP link is negotiated during LCP negotiation.
Prerequisites
PPP is configured as the link layer protocol of the interface.
Configuration Impact
Changing the configuration triggers PPP renegotiation.
Precautions
After the configuration, you must run the shutdown, commit, and undo shutdown commands in the corresponding interface view for the configuration to take effect.
